The rumbling sound has cascaded into a deafening, cacophonous white noise of alarms, collapsing buildings, and screams."

hi <!channel>.  sorry to interrupt all of the darkness.

regarding chronos (project resource):  there is still work to be done in gettting resources, in conjunction with harvest and float, to work for you. based on the feedback i’ve received, i hatched a plan to solve some continued problems. spencer is working with float, harvest, and slack’s APIs to carry out the plan. here’s the general idea: 

1) create an uncorked branded email for your float schedule that comes with an .ics file. this will allow you to save your float schedule to your google calendar. now you can adjust your schedule based on what you can tackle when. this will be more useful for some than others. (thanks for your help with this phillip!)

2) build a site for producers to request resources. this is most useful to myself as the resource manager and the producers, but we’ll be working on asking producers better questions about what they need from you so there is more clarity for you on  assignments. 

3) remember the calendar .ics you’ll be receiving with your schedule? we’re going to work on a way for you to export your google calendar to harvest. the idea here is that you’ll be able to easily export all of your assigned hours and meeting hours to harvest and then make notes and edit. some of you will choose to continue using timers and this isn’t meant to discourage that. it’s meant to be an option for other who aren’t as great about it ( :hand: ).

so, please take the survey spencer sent. and as always, *please* send me any questions, comments, concerns, or feedback. if you have an idea on how to make this better, i’m all ears.
thanks for trying to improve the current process <@U04JZANJF> and <@U026PT0D7> !
<@U02E3CRMA> is in on it too! he's done most of the (code) architecting
yes, of course! thank you for helping me flesh out and hatch this plan <@U02E3CRMA>!
thanks joel!
also, you should all watch the survivalists episode of louis theroux. the safest place from all natural disasters is somewhere in idaho.
<@U04JZANJF> One little piece of feedback is that I don’t really know enough of how the current system works to answer some of the survey questions.
I'm not sure I know enough to be able to answer any of the questions in the survey.

re: knowledge. That's fine! I mostly just want to know about how you feel about YOUR interaction with the system. Do you love Harvest? Do you always forget to start your timers? Do you wish your Float email were daily instead of weekly?
Actually, maybe I just don't have any problems with the way it is now.... so nm!
that's ok too!

Got it! Here’s the flow:

Wednesday - I ping all of the producers and execs to send me their resource requests for the next week using this format:

Client: 
Project Name: 
Resources

Discipline (Designer, Developer, Other)
Name: 
Hours: 
Needs: 

Thursday - I’ve received all resource requests and manually input them into Float. 

Friday - I send your Float schedule for the next week and ask for your feedback. Then the producers, Marce, and John have a resources meeting Friday afternoon. We discuss any conflicts, people whose schedule are overburdened, OOOs, etc. 

From there I do my best to leave Float alone for that week. Float is meant to show us what resources we predict we’ll use. Harvest is meant to show us what we used.
<@U02618EV1> let me know if that makes sense.

From this follows one obvious introspection we can get out of the data: Are we making accurate estimates? I know I'm always at least a little bit off with my estimates on coding, so I'm pretty excited to see this data
Thanks <@U04JZANJF>. Makes perfect sense.
<@U026PT0D7>: Are we taking into account scope changes, impromptu meetings, events, etc?
I'm not sure yet what level of granularity we'll have

good point! some retrospective reconciliation w/r/t harvest and float would be good (ie this person was scheduled but ended up not working, or this person was scheduled for 15 hours but worked 20, alert producer to manage). And <@U02618EV1> hopefully those don’t happen often enough to need mechanisms, but I think producers should be taking into account any padding for necessary meetings when making requests.

for example: a Float task for 20 hours of development on Project X, then a Harvest timer for 30 hours of development. And here "development" would be a task within the data structure of each service. So at some point there will be a matching between a given Float Task and a Harvest Task
In my (short) experience, estimates are somewhat accurate but what makes projects late are scope changes, and other factors. Happy to share multiple examples if needed.
Yeah I hear that. I'm not sure how to track scope changes
Also not sure if tracking scope changes would be a scope change for Chronos...is that irony?
<@U02618EV1> totally agree. part of this project is to hopefully collect some data over time so we can see how often this happens.
what we identify as useful and what we bite off for a given increment of delivery are separate decisions.

attachments.title: Shake up the gallery: how iPads are changing the way we visit museums
attachments.text: From where I am at the moment, there’s only one place from which you can see the Eiffel Tower, and I have to fight through a crowd of kids to get to it.
attachments.fallback: Alphr: Shake up the gallery: how iPads are changing the way we visit museums

text: some interesting museum work referenced - gamification to increase people engaging with the actual museum space, second screen/canvas experiences for sketches and history
great article
